_exec_summary.SummaryText:
a safety manner.

Any training required under Management of Change will be completed prior to the startup of the change. Experienced Unit Trainers, who have direct input into the training materials and training methods, conduct initial and refresher training for the hourly employees involved in operating the process. The initial and refresher training is a combination of Computer Based Training (CBT), classroom, one-to-one training with the Trainer, job shadowing, and hands on training. Refresher training is conducted every three (3) years for operators and is a combination of CBT and one-to-one training. Safety training is a combination of CBT and classroom and is held annually for all required OSHA training. Emergency Response Training is held as required by the applicable regulation. Training records are maintained on the Training Department data base. The Operations Department in conjunction with the Training Department verifies that operators on the units are current with their required training. Maintenance training is conducted by the Training Department as either in-house or third-party training (i.e. certification of crane operators). Further, the Training Department provides specialized training such as forklift certification either in-house or by a third-party provider. Engineers and other salaried personnel are provided with third-party training to continue or advance their skills. Safety training is a combination of both CBT and classroom. All training is documented and credited to the employee's personnel record.

CONTRACTORS - Alon USA requests and obtains information regarding the contractor's safety performance and programs. The information is used as part of the contractor evaluation process.

Contractors are approved through the Alon Contractor Approval Process that is currently provided by ISNETWORLD, a nationally recognized network for approval of contractors. Policy 101.6 also applies to the approval of contractors who must maintain a mi

urrently plan to implement came from these hazard reviews. Below are improvements under review:

102' LTI aerial platform fire truck, 3k gpm pump, 1k gallon foam.
Upgrades to the firewater distribution system, North Pond, 5k Pump, additional piping distribution.
Implementation and adherence to Homeland Security ASP and CISA directives.
Perimeter monitoring for air releases.
Perimeter camera systems for improved site security.
Upgrading selective pumps to tandem seals with alarms.
Continued improvements to structural fireproofing.
Continued inspections for corrosion under insulation.
Continued installation of burner management systems.
Upgrades to policies and procedures including a new frequency of review system.
Improvements to the training facilities for emergency response.
Continuation of the alarm rationalization process.
Quarterly table-top drills.
Participation in the OSHA Challenge Program while working to become a VPP site.

e Big Spring Refinery involve hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program is applied to all RMP-covered processes. Collectively, these activities help prevent potential accidents that could be caused by equipment failure and / or human error. In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Alon has safety features on many units to help 1) contain / control a release, 2) quickly detect a release, and 3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes: release detection, hydrocarbon detectors with alarms, hydrofluoric acid detectors with alarms, hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms, personal hydrogen sulfide detectors worn while in the units, process relief devices that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases, valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated), emergency shutdown systems, curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases, redundant equipment and instrumentation, double seals on specific pumps, atmospheric relief devices, water curtain in the HF area, water cannons, deluge system on sphere 73, fire suppression and extinguishing systems, and trained emergency response personnel.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the past five years, Alon had one reportable RMP incident. On February 17, 2021 a fire started on the west end of the Alkylation Unit. The Emergency Response Team quickly responded by using water cannons and dry chemicals to put out the fire and contain the area. The fire resulted in significant property damage, but none resulted in human injuries, deaths or any off-site consequences. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Alon Refinery is continually seeking to improve the safety of the facility. As part of our efforts to continually improve and reduce the risk of our processes we periodically evaluate the hazards of our operations. Some of the safety improvement items we c

n is communicated to and coordinated with local groups including the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and responders such as the Big Spring Fire Department, the Howard County Sheriff's Department, the Big Spring Police Department, the Texas Department of Public Safety and the Howard County Volunteer Fire Department. These groups are used to supplement the efforts of the Alon USA Emergency Response and HAZMAT teams that take direct control to handle the emergency on-site.

Communication on-site includes a warning siren system and individual portable radios. Communication to the public is coordinated through the LEPC and 911 systems which, in turn, include notifications through the local radio and cable TV stations.

Routine, joint training exercises are conducted to insure a coordinated, timely and appropriate response will occur in the unlikely event of a release actually occurring. The refinery has developed a comprehensive Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) that defines the levels of response along with the roles and responsibilities of the responders. The refinery has standardized on the National Information Management System (NIMS) in order to be able to seamlessly integrate with outside responding agencies. As members of one or more of the refinery Emergency Response Teams (REDHATS), refinery personnel participate in classroom training, onsite training, offsite training, drills, and real incidents inside the refinery. The refinery maintains a Hazardous Materials and Emergency Response (HAZMAT) team, High Angle Rescue Team, Confined Space Rescue Team, Medical Response Team, and Fire Department with both incipient level and certified fire fighters. The site has personnel trained in CPR and First Aid along with some higher level medical responders. Managers or designees comprise an integral part of the response team by serving in the Emergency Operations Center in the staff positions of NIMS.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at th

hree years, an outside audit is conducted to assess the adherence to the OSHA PSM Standard and EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP). The auditors develop findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented.

Employees participate in compliance audits by assisting in the collection of information prior to and during the performance of the audit. Also, all employees and contractor personnel are subject to being interviewed during the audit to assure that they are knowledgeable of the PSM elements and that they are following policies and procedures. Employees participate in the Hazard Recognition (HAZREC) Audits conducted monthly so that all units are covered on a quarterly basis. Safety observations are conducted as part of the VPP initiative. During turnarounds, job and site audits are conducted by employees, contractors, and safety personnel.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM - The Alon USA Big Spring Refinery Emergency Response (ER) Plan describes the organization, responsibilities, and plans for responding to emergencies. The ER Plan is available at the workplace for employee review; many employees are involved in multiple aspects of this plan. The plan is reviewed and updated at least annually prior to the required drill regarding salt well storage facilities. Outside agencies are invited to a minimum of one major drill each year (Salt Well Drill) and the local fire departments are invited to joint training exercises with the refinery emergency response team.

Affected personnel assigned new responsibilities or designated actions receive training upon assignment of those new duties. General refresher training is completed after the yearly update and prior to the annual drill.  Newly assigned personnel review the portions of the ER Plan they must know to protect themselves in the event of an emergency. This pla

very incident that results in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace. All employees and contractors are responsible for reporting incidents and injuries so that they can be investigated. All persons involved in an incident are interviewed to determine what happened in order to prevent a reoccurrence. Incidents are reported in the plant data management system, and action items related to those incidents are also input and tracked in the data management system. Incidents are investigated at different levels depending on the severity of the incident. The refinery is currently using the 5-Why method of investigated near miss and minor incidents. The teams assigned to those investigations are supervisors and subject matter experts (SMEs) associated with the area where the incident occurred. Higher level events receive a root- cause type of investigation that is comprised of a team leader, representatives from the affected area, SMEs, and others as needed.

Team members include at least one member familiar with the covered process, a represented worker appropriate for the investigation, a contract employee if the incident involved the work of a contractor and others with appropriate technical knowledge and experience as needed to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. The investigation team issues a report, per the approved procedures, to the Big Spring Refinery Health, Safety, & Environmental (HSE) Committee. The HSE Committee reviews and approves the final version of all Incident Investigation Reports including all accepted recommendations. Incident Investigations are prepared under the guidelines outlined in
the Incident Investigation Procedure 217.0.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS - To ensure that the PSM / RMP programs are functioning properly, Alon USA periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the program are being implemented. At least every t

rform certain gas testing prior to issuing permits. The Safety Department writes the Level 2 Hot Work and Confined Space Entry Permits along with providing the necessary gas testing for those permits. Employees have the opportunity to provide input in the development of Safe Work Practices through participation in the Safety and Health Policies and Procedures Committee which meets to review Safe Work Policies and Procedures.  Operations' employees, maintenance employees, contractor employees when applicable, and possibly safety representatives participate in the Job Safety Analysis (JSA) that is performed prior to work beginning on that task.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE (MOC) - Alon USA developed, implemented, and utilizes written procedures to manage changes to facilities, process chemicals, technologies, or equipment, other than replacement in kind. This insures the collection of relevant information to keep Mechanical Integrity and process safety information files current. Authorized employees in the refinery can originate a Management of Change (MOC) for their area.  Employees are involved in many aspects of the management of change procedure such as updating documentation, training, notification and performing the work related to the change, Health Safety Impact Reviews (HSIRs), Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) such as a HAZOP when needed, and PSSRs.

Affected employees and contractors involved in the operation or maintenance of a process are informed of and trained in the change prior to start-up of the process or affected part of the process. If the change results in a change in the PSI or Ml Files, such PSI and Ml information is updated accordingly. If the change results in a change to the operating procedures or practices, such procedures or practices are updated accordingly. Completed MOCs are housed in files located in the Process Safety Department. Policy 216.0 is the general MOC procedure.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION - Alon USA investigates, as a minimum, e

and on-going integrity of process equipment by determining and documenting the equipment is designed, installed and maintained properly for the intended service. Employees have the opportunity to provide input in the development of the procedures applicable to their job tasks. Employees are an integral part of the inspecting and testing of process piping, instrumentation and equipment.  Each employee involved in maintaining the integrity of the process equipment will be trained in an overview of that process, the hazards of the process, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks to assure the employee can perform the tasks in a safe manner.

The Inspection Department is comprised of both Alon and contract personnel. Inspectors, technicians, and craftsmen meet the qualifications required for the work they perform. The Inspection Department at the Alon Refinery stores the information related to inspections and mechanical integrity of piping and vessels. PCMS is used to facilitate the inspection process. Hard copies of certain information are maintained in the Project Engineering Department Library. Policy 101.8 is an integral part of the mechanical integrity process.

The Ml Department follows the Alon specifications along with those from outside agencies such as API, ASME, ASTM, UL, NFPA, and others when conducting their inspections or recommending replacement of piping and equipment.

SAFE WORK PRACTICES- Safe work practices/procedures are used to control hazards during operation and maintenance activities. These procedures are available to all employees on the Big Spring Refinery Home page Electronic Data Locator (EDL). Alon has developed and implemented procedures for Hot Work Permits along with other Safe Work Practices in areas such as confined space entry, line and vessel entry, site access, and lockout / tagout (LOTO). Employees issue the Work Authorization Permits (WAPs), monitor the work area while the work is being performed, and pe

ty Department to review their qualifications and policies. Contractors who have issues while on site are requested to have special meetings with their Alon contact and the Safety Department before continuing their work.

Alon informs all contractors of the known potential site hazards of fire, explosion or toxic releases related to the contract work and explains to contract employers the applicable provisions of the Emergency Response Plan. Contractors are responsible to inform Alon of any unique hazards presented by the contract employer's work or about any chemicals brought to the refinery. Sufficient controls are in place by Alon USA to control the entrance and exit of contractors from the facility plus their presence in the covered process units. Alon USA periodically audits the performance of the contractors in fulfilling their obligations. Alon USA maintains a contractor injury and illness log related to the contractor's work in the units.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW (PSSR) - A pre-startup safety review is conducted for new facilities as well as existing facilities that have been modified to the extent that the process safety information has been changed. The PSSR is defined by policy 228.0. Employees participate in this element by their involvement in the PSSR as a member of the PSSR team. Employees may be selected either by the area in which they work or by their expertise. The PSSR requires operators, maintenance personnel, safety, process safety, environmental, process engineering, possibly project engineering, possibly mechanical integrity, and other specialty personnel to review the installation of new or revised equipment prior to start-up of that equipment. Checklists are provided for each area that is required to participate to ensure the equipment is ready to be placed into service. The PSSR becomes part of the permanent record of the MOC and is stored in the PSM Department.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY - Mechanical Integrity efforts assure the initial

nimum of a C rating in ISNETWORLD with contractors who have higher grades (B or A) getting preference. Once approved, the contractor employee must attend training provided through the Association of Reciprocal Safety Council (ARSC) Network. This may be done at any of the ARSC locations around the country. In addition, each contractor employee must be trained on the site specific orientation (provides information on hazards in the refinery and the emergency plan) for the Alon Refinery. This may be done at a Reciprocal Safety Council Network Site or on the ISNETWORLD Web site. Both training sessions are required for entry at the Alon Refinery. Contractors are involved in monthly safety meetings, safety audits, and incident investigations when one of their employees is involved in the incident. Contractors are involved in routine drills to ensure their employees can locate assembly points in the event of an emergency. Numerous contractor employees work with or are under the direction of Alon employees and are expected to follow all refinery HS&E rules including those pertaining to PSM. Contractor employees participate in the JSAs conducted prior to performing work on the units and obtain their work permits from Alon employees who have checked the area for hazards prior to issuing the permit(s). Contractors are encouraged to participate in the refinery effort to become a Voluntary Protection Program Site (OSHA VPP). All contractor employees are empowered to stop an unsafe job (just as Alon employees).

Contractors are provided with a copy of the process overviews for refinery units and with the refinery safety policies prior to coming onto the refinery property to begin work. It is the responsibility of the contractor to ensure their employees are provided with an overview of the hazards and safety policies before coming to the refinery.

Specialty contractors, such as those who provide inert entry services, meet annually with refinery personnel including the Safe

working with the unit trainers to develop the operating procedures for the units. Operators, Unit Superintendents, the Operations' Manager, Unit Process Engineers, Unit Coordinators, Unit Trainers, Shift Leaders, Process Control Engineer for alarm rationalization, Operations Training Coordinator, Process Safety Director and others are involved in writing, reviewing, and approving the operating instructions. The Unit Superintendents and Operations' Manager are responsible for the yearly certification of the instructions.

New or significantly revised (more than 25% of content changed) are required to be approved through the Management of Change Process.

Maintenance procedures are developed by utilizing the expertise of craftsmen, superintendents, and the maintenance manager. The Maintenance Department maintains these procedures in electronic and paper form. They are updated as needed to keep them current. Manufacturer recommended procedures are also retained for specific equipment.

TRAINING - Alon has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the processes in the refinery. Prior to working in the refinery, accepting a shift assignment and before operating or maintaining any process equipment, new employees (hourly and salaried) are trained in fundamental information related to essential safety, environmental, health, teamwork, quality, basic skills, and process overview specific to the hazards the employee may be exposed to while performing work. Prior to start-up of a new or modified process, employees assigned to the units will be trained in an overview of the process and the operating procedures for the new equipment or process.

After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. Operators may work independently only after showing (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) adequate knowledge to perform job duties and tasks in

s Engineering, and Health, Safety, Security and Environmental. The Director of Process Safety conducts the vetting meeting and records the results including the assignment of action items with responsible persons and completion dates. The accepted PSM recommendations will be documented in the electronic tracking system and resolved in a timely manner based upon a priority that is based primarily upon current risk and overall risk reduction afforded by the recommendation. Members of the PHA team along with supervision from the affected area may attend the vetting meeting. Any rejected recommendation is recorded in the tracking system along with the justification for rejection.

Process Hazard Analyses Timing - Each unit PHA is updated and revalidated within five years of the initial or last major PHA study. The refinery adopted a policy in 2016 that PHAs would be on an end date-to-end date basis in order to ensure the five-year period was met.

Retention of PHA's - All PHA and corrective action documentation are retained in the technical files for the life of the process involved.

OPERATING PROCEDURES - The refinery has developed and compiled a comprehensive set of operating procedures to provide instruction in the safe operation of the refinery. Procedures must provide a reliable and consistent reference for all phases of process operations including 1) unit startup, 2) normal operations, 3) temporary operations, 4) emergency shutdowns, 5) normal shutdown, 6) initial startup of a new process, 7) emergency operations, and 8) startup following an abnormal or emergency shutdown.

Each procedure is reviewed for accuracy, consistency, and completeness. The procedures contain procedure steps, operating parameters and limits, safety and health information, safety control measures, and assignment of responsibility for performing the procedure. Current operating procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified.

Experienced operators are responsible for

ge of the process, extent of hazards, number of potentially affected employees, and operating history. The method of choice used at the Big Spring refinery for initial PHA's was the Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOP). It remains the most common form of PHA conducted. Refinery Policy 101.3 provides overall guidance for the PHA, which can include a Level of Protection Analysis (LOPA).

For a HAZOP, the minimum team will consist of one process operator with knowledge and experience of the process unit being reviewed, the process engineer for that unit, the unit supervisor or designee, one individual with specialized training in facilitating a HAZOP, and one PHA scribe (generally the PSM Administrative Assistant). Generally, a rotating equipment specialist from maintenance, a member of the mechanical integrity group, and a process instrumentation group are also members. Other Subject Matter Experts (SME) are invited as needed.

Refinery personnel will be involved in the PHAs conducted for Capital Engineering Projects in anticipation of major upgrades or installation of new equipment in the refinery. Those involved will include representatives from the HSSE Department along with all other appropriate departments.

PHAs will be conducted prior to initial startup of a new unit, prior to recommissioning an out-of- service unit, and as a minimum, every five years for each operating unit. PHAs for units will be located in the PSM Department. Action items from the PHAs will be placed on the electronic data base (currently IMPACT) and will be available to all plant personnel. Results of all PHAs will be communicated to affected employees and contractors who have the potential to be exposed to the hazards on that unit.

Documentation of PHA Findings - The PHA team findings and recommendations are vetted by the management committee comprised of the Vice President of Refining for Big Spring along with the managers of Operations, Maintenance, Capital Engineering, Proces

of the chemicals used in a covered process as well as information of the process technology and specified equipment. This information is available before conducting the hazard analysis and is available for review by hard copy or electronically to all employees. Employees assist in developing this information by supplying, reviewing, and correcting information pertaining to the hazards, equipment, and technology of the processes. Currently, all PSI is updated by use of the Management of Change (MOC) system along the Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) system. Employees are provided access to all process safety information related to the equipment, technology of the process, dangers of acutely and chronically hazardous chemicals, along with flammable materials used in the process. Piping and Instrument Diagrams (P&ID) are maintained by the engineering department in electronic files available online to employees. Process overviews along with operating instructions are electronically available to all employees. This includes maximum intended inventories of materials on the units. Safety Data Sheets are available online through MSDSONLINE on the plant intranet. Other PSI is housed in the Technical Department (Process Safety), Engineering Department (Mechanical Integrity, drafting, new projects), Maintenance Department (Mechanical Integrity, Rotating Equipment, Preventative Maintenance), HSSE Department (PHAs, MOCs, General Training and Re-certification, Incident Investigations, Contractor Certifications), and Operations Department (Operating Instructions, Unit Operator Training). Policy 101.2 is written to support the collection and storage of PSI information.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA) - Assigned teams, as specified by the PSM standard, have performed hazard analyses to identify, evaluate and control hazards involved in each covered process. The analysis was appropriate to the complexity of the process and scheduled based upon various prioritized factors including a

CCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS 

The prevention program is designed to prevent a release from occurring. The BSR accidental release prevention program includes all of the elements of both PSM and RMP regulations. Key to these prevention efforts is the knowledge of the chemicals and equipment used in the process units, the careful evaluation of and reduction of operating risks, and the proper operation, monitoring, upkeep and maintenance of equipment and systems. These ongoing efforts substantially reduce the likelihood of severe accidental release event (toxic or flammable) occurring at the BSR. The mitigation systems currently in place and the prompt response by experienced and qualified personnel would further limit the worst case or alternate scenarios to much less than the estimated impacted areas if they did occur. The following is more detailed information regarding our risk management and incident prevention program currently in place.

The Alon USA BSR Accidental Release Prevention Program includes the following elements:

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION - All Alon USA Big Spring employees are involved in risk management efforts. This involvement includes assistance in identifying and correcting hazards, assistance in conceptual design of improvements and new installations, reviewing and revising operating procedures, pre-startup safety reviews, training, operation and maintenance of equipment, development of maintenance procedures, and the safe operation of the plant. Selected employees, including represented ones, are members of special teams for Incident Investigations, Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) evaluations, reviewing policies and procedures (Policy and Procedure Committee), the Health & Safety Committee, and the Risk Management Committee, while others are directly involved in the writing and reviews of the operating and maintenance procedures.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION (PSI) - PSI is the written process safety information on the hazards

Executive Summary of Risk Management Plan for the Alon USA Big Spring Refinery

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Alon USA has a long-standing commitment to the safety and health of our community and workers and protection of the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. If a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond quickly and effectively to control and mitigate the release. In an effort to reduce the risk of accidental releases from this facility it is the policy of the Alon USA Big Spring Refinery (BSR) to comply with the requirements of both 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Materials (PSM), and 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (a.k.a. Risk Management Program, or RMP), regulatory requirements. We have verified compliance with these important regulations.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The BSR is a 73,000 barrels per day crude oil refinery located in Big Spring, Texas with a Nelson Complexity of 10.5. BSR produces transportation fuels, solvents, finished asphalt, and Liquefied Petroleum Gases (LPG's). The refinery has more than the threshold quantity of several flammable substances and flammable mixtures and two toxic substance (hydrogen fluoride and anhydrous ammonia). Hydrogen Fluoride is used as a catalyst in the production of gasoline blend stock in the Alkylation Unit. Ammonia is used to reduce atmospheric emissions of Nitrogen Oxides from the boilers.

In 2022, the refinery reports thirteen (13) Program 3 RMP-regulated processes and seven (7) Program 1 RMP-regulated processes. The remaining processes were documented as not being RMP applicable. 

GENERAL A
